sen.j: 蘇我氏の血を引かない敏達王統の最有力者であって、忍坂部（刑部氏）・丸子部などの独立した財政基盤を有し、王都を離れて水派宮（みまたのみや、奈良県河合町か）を営んでいた。
sen.e: He was the most powerful person among the imperial family outside of the Soga clan origin, and owned independent financial foundations such as Otsusakabe (忍坂部, also written 刑部) and the Marukobe, and ran Mimata no miya (Kawai-cho, Nara Prefecture) away from the imperial capital.

sen.j: 用明天皇の崩御（587年）後に王位継承者として候補に挙がったらしいが、対立する蘇我系王族が台頭したため、以後の史料には活動が一切見えず、蘇我氏によって暗殺されたとの憶測もある。
sen.e: After Emperor Yomei died in 587, he was raised up as the successor to the throne, but it is assumed that he was assassinated by the Soga clan since none of his further activities were recorded in any historical documents after the royal family related to the Soga clan, opposed to Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko, gained power.

sen.j: ただし、『一代要記』や『本朝皇胤紹運録』を基に逆算される舒明の生年（593年）とその弟の存在を考えると、592年の推古天皇即位後もしばらく生存していたはずで、非蘇我系の王位継承候補者として、蘇我系の竹田皇子や聖徳太子と比肩し得る地位を保っていたと思われる。
sen.e: But he must have been alive for a while after Empress Suiko was enthroned in 592 considering Jomei's year of birth (593) and the existence of his younger brother, and it is assumed that he held equal power as a candidate of successor to the throne with Takeda no miko, the Soga clan origin, and Prince Shotoku.

But he must have been alive for a while after the Empress Suiko was enthroned in 592, according to the birth year of the Emperor Jomei, calculated back based on "Ichidai Yoki (summary chronicle of each reign), "Honcho koin jounroku" (the Emperor's family tree, made in the Muromachi period) and the existence of his brother; it is assumed that he held the equal power as a candidate of the successor to the throne with Takeda no miko, the Soga clan origin, and the Prince Shotoku.

sen.j: 忍坂部や丸子部といった押坂彦人大兄皇子伝来の私領は「皇祖大兄御名入部」と呼ばれて、以後も息子である舒明から孫の中大兄皇子（後の天智天皇）らへと引き継がれて、大化の改新後に国家に返納された（『日本書紀』大化2年3月20日_(旧暦)条）と考えられている。
sen.e: Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko's hereditary private properties such as Otsusakabe and Marukobe were called "皇祖大兄御名入部" and handed over to his son of Emperor Jomei and grandson of Naka no Oe no Oji (later Emperor Tenchi) and it is believed that such private properties were returned to the nation after Taika no Kaishin (Great Reformation of the Taika Era) (April 13, 646 section in "Nihonshoki" [Chronicles of Japan]).
